they’re trying to help him. i have no idea if he’s actually read any of the sites on here, but i’m just going to assume that he hasn’t. if he did, and if he had done any research on the sites he is managing, he’d realize that the interest and clicks they garner are a result of the writers, more so than virtually any other media group. people don’t read deadspin because they want some conventional sports story, they read because they want to hear what the writers actually want to say. same thing with jalopnik and the other sites. deadspin was going to die anyway if spanfeller’s ad system and insistence on only covering sports continued. the writers saw the writing on the wall and tried to get his attention before it was to late. clearly he didn’t like hearing the truth, had an ego tantrum, and fired deadspin’s editor. i get if you don’t care about deadspin at all, but jalopnik’s days are also numbered if this is the way spanfeller is going to go about things.

i have a theory as to who performance suv and cross-overs are for: those with wealth-gilt. i honestly think performance suvs have become so popular, in part, as they satisfy the wealthy’s urge to spend money on extravagant, expensive and exclusive things, while still maintaining some false sense of solidarity with the common folk (“hey, we’re all out here just driving suvs!”) and without ostentatiously advertising to the world how wealthy they are. i don’t think john q public realizes that the price of many of those examples are as absurd as they are - they probably don’t notice an x5m as being any different than a base x5, though the former is $100k+, and the latter mid-$60s. on the other hand, if the average person sees someone in a $100k sports car, they’re going to notice and think the driver is very well off. in short, those that matter, know, and those that don’t, are none the wiser.

i bought a 1998 4wd last year to use as my “adventure
mobile.” i was thinking around $3,000 and something bigger (for more camping
stuff) and with a higher ground clearance than my 1998 subaru wagon. i was
looking at beat third gen 4runners when i saw an ad for one of these at $3,000.
the couple i bought it from were going to drive from montana to alaska in the
mpv, but they never would have made it. it had the usual copious top engine oil
leaks—if they didn’t have an engine fire, then sooner or later the oil-soaked
coolant hoses would have burst. plus, the starter would have given out (as it
did for me) because it was saturated in oil, and the starters on 4wd mpvs are
notoriously hard to get at. plus, the van spent its early years in nebraska
where they salt the roads, and because of the plentiful rust, i was able to
bargain the purchase price down to $1,600. it cost $800 to a mechanic to fix
the oil seals and replace the hoses, and another $800 to install a new starter.

i feel like the average skill level for drivers, including just paying attention, has declined since the advent of the cell phone and of the “connected” car. there have always been distractions; one terrible incident in california involved a young girl who was reaching down to pick up a cassette (this was of course 20-30 years ago or so), and killed a bunch of bicyclists. but now everybody is looking at their phone at all times, and i won’t pretend i’m not occasionally guilty when in slow-moving traffic, but i try to be aware of the consequences (and i live in fear of the person behind me rear-ending me because they’re not looking). what’s infuriating is that it’s now almost the default; we crave the information, the text, the update, and i often see people drifting, usually to the right, and going slower or not keeping up with traffic, and their doing something with their phone or car infotainment is the only thing that comes to mind as an explanation. the average skill level of drivers will only get worse, as semi-automated cars become more prevalent, because people will have to hone their skills less and less.   nobody’s willing to give up the high, and car makers and governments won’t buck the amount of money to be made advertising and selling to us every single second, so like deaths from alcohol, it will continue and get worse even though a technological solution such as not allowing phones to work while the car’s in motion (and too bad for the passengers), is certainly possible but will just never happen. the overall sense that nobody’s paying attention and can change lanes / cross over with no warning because they are distracted, has sucked a lot of the fun out of casual driving and injected a random sense of unease into even the everyday errand.

as an example, apparently if you ask anyone who has driven a tesla if they would rather drive it or something else in the same class, they will almost universally choose the tesla. i’ve heard this over and over, and given that tesla doesn’t even offer test drives in most markets i have to question whether it’s true. that doesn’t change the story, though, and that’s the kind of marketing you cannot get with a cool tv ad aimed at soccer moms or guys who love their big trucks. nobody else instills a “i really want to drive this car” vibe with their viral marketing. at best in today’s us market, you do some research, then go to a lot for a car that suits your needs, and if the thing doesn’t sound like it’s going to rattle apart when you test drive it, you buy it. nobody even tries to instill a “once you drive this, you will not want to drive anything else” feeling, but tesla has managed to do just that even before you drive it. that’s why they are selling cars to people who have barely ever seen one in a parking lot, let alone ever driven one.

the engine in the e-type was definitely better, but styling? not remotely. i remember disagreeing with that when i first read that opinion about 30 years ago when japanese cars were still openly disregarded. every gt car had the short deck/long hood with the shoulder line dropping over the wheels, but—if anything—the toyota is far more ferrari gto for the curves than the phallic mess of the e-type’s front (everything behind the a-pillar on the earlier roadsters is great, but i hate that long, flat-ish hood. people post the snl penis car all the time, but about the only car that actually conjures that image for me is the e-type), the fhc roof is far more awkwardly resolved, and it has a goofy-looking narrow track tucked under the wheelarches that’s ostensibly for aerodynamics, but makes the turning circle so wide that the car is nearly useless to maneuver anywhere that more than 15 degrees of lock would come in handy (and the toyota is probably a better car, as well—i worked on an e-type and it was obviously built to be a disposable bauble for the affluent of the time). the toyota is about 4/5 the size, has proper wheelarches and track width, is more curvy with razor edges to the curves, has a closer ratio of hood length to passenger compartment length, totally different detailing (ffs, it has pop up headlights where the e-type doesn’t), and the back is closer to a kammback than the e-type’s horizontal pinch. i will grant that the center exhaust is very similar.

nobody seems to say that the shelby daytona cobra is a gto copy! if it were european, the toyota would have been appreciated long before, but because it was japanese (even though it was designed by a german) it got the “copy of xx” dismissal. if the two can’t be told apart, then why pick the e-type when so many other gt cars would fit just as well.

this isn’t surprising. moving margin out of advertised price and into back end fees is common in many industries with heavy price comparison and no external entity setting a common expectation point (i.e. an msrp). consumer data shows time and time again that comparison shopping is done purely on “menu item price,” not on final price. once a single entity in a market starts this game, it becomes an arms race for all competitors to do it, because now their prices no longer look competitive at first blush.

autotrader or cars.com. an analogy? i have a walmart card. i get 1% cash back in the store. but 3% online. they don’t have you in the store. i get 5% cash back with target or amazon. online you can click away from their website in seconds. i’m disabled. i buy everything online. dealers online price has to be their best price. i’m in the philadelphia area. my sister is in the nyc area. a year ago i was looking for a vw alltrack for her. found exactly what she wanted at a dealership in rockville, md. between baltimore and dc. about 2.5 hours south of my apt in the philly suburbs. she’s only 90 minutes north in northern nj. so a further drive for them. it was about $12,000 below sticker. 11 months old with 14,000 miles on it. and amazingly, it was certified. so the vw warranty was now 4 miles. doubling the standard warranty. not worth the extra $12,000 though. it was a loaded se model. everything was done by phone. on sunday, july 29th, the salesman and his wife drive it up from md. i sold cars once. they certainly wanted to get the deal in for july. they signed the papers at my kitchen table. we transferred her stuff from her trade in the parking lot. and they drove her trade back. the dealer could be local. you’ll still get the best price online. as in my walmart example. in this era of online shopping, on amazon sellers will drop their price by cents if another one does. so that they can be the lowest. my charger was a different story. certainly no shortage ol used inventory anywhere. but i wanted it exactly as i’d have ordered it new. not easy on s used car. i found i have financing through lightstream right now.

i can give atleast the testimony that the experience was painless.... but that the interest rate advertised is not what you will qualify for. it said i would be as low as 3.35%, was offered 3.85 and negotiated them to 3.55 based on a competitive offer from my credit union at 3.6%.

and i know everyone says “i know my credit”. i monitor my credit like a hawk, i know my score, my credit profile information, everything. if i didn’t qualify for the lowest advertised rate (the lightstream guy said required a 740 vs my 800+ at the time), i wonder who does.

that aside, the loan was otherwise painless, transferred funds quickly, helped me line up inspections, etc.

regardless of the model year not actually matching the production date, the model year nomenclature really helps out consumers. the manufacturers will typically do minor changes and updates to car models as they evolve. do to how supply chains and negotiations with suppliers work it is easier to have a set date on when they switch over from the “old design” to the “new design”. this can usually coincide with a maintenance shut down of the factory as well. that makes it easier to determine what features and fixes a car may have come with based on the model year number. barring the occasional “mid model year change” most changes to cars will take place at the model year change drop date in the factory. even without changes though, a model year can only cross one january 1st. that means that the model year change date will usually coincide with some kind of major maintenance shut down of the factory which is usually late spring/early summer but can go as far as fall. because manufacturers don’t want to look outdated compared to competitors they will start advertising the new model year as early as possible so that they have 2020 models on the lots compared to their competitors “old” 2019s.  i much prefer the model year nomenclature rather than the date of registration model that europe uses.  a car that sits for a year or 2 europe will have the same registration year as a car that arrives from the factory and is sold on the same day as the old car.  that old car could even be a different generation but still be registered as the same model year.

i have a collection of over 180 vintage car advertisements ranging from 1946 to 1964, which i got because i was in an art class that had a bunch of old national geographic magazines for the students to use as “art fodder”. i spent most of my spare time searching through those magazines for vintage car ads, which the teacher let me take home. advertisers got pretty creative back then and tried all sorts of different approaches to selling cars. i don’t think any of mine are quite as weird as that simca ad, but i do have some odd ones. i have a 1957 ford ad that advertises both ford and new england, a 1956 chevy ad that implies that people named jones are particularly good at picking cars, and a renault dauphine ad that features a character that (i think) comes from a children’s book and suggests that you buy a dauphine on a trip to europe instead of using public transportation, claiming that you’d save money and also be able to import the dauphine to america.
i think that, in the cursive writing at the edge of legibility, the chevy ad punches the implied premise of “keeping up with the joneses.”

i work for mazda as well and mazda is making a huge push to dealers to improve the experience. dealerships are visited frequently and have training seminars with the sales people (which are mandatory in order for us to get paid by mazda) yet we are not compensated at all for the meetings/seminars. also mazda does have policies in place about how a dealership is allowed to price a car via a buying program or online advertisement. truecar quotes, edmunds quotes... etc. if you are caught quoting under invoice you can be penalized. so those dealers are probably afraid you count as one of those sources... or maybe they are just playing games. i'm not saying there are no bad dealers left out there. but mazda is definitely pushing to improve customer experience. it affects how we are paid majorly. one bad survey from one single customer could literally cost me personally as a salesman about $5,000 and it affects your entire quarter. it's not a month to month and the scale. i can't imagine our dealership wouldn't quote you and some of those stories sound crazy. our cars definitely aren't limited as they come off the truck, but like i said, mazda is definitely making a huge push towards a premium experience. they made loaner cars mandatory. every dealer must supply them free of charge. they hired an outside company that allegedly trained mercedes employees to come in and work with us... they are doing so much to push the experience.

not sure about toyota, but bmw na and mb usa forbid their dealers from advertising that way (via not paying the ad subsidies), and any rebates they ever do (which happen more than you know) are strictly to the dealer. if you can find the information, you can save a ton on a car. when the last z4 m’s were at dealers 11 years ago, there was a $13,000 rebate to the dealer. the smart people ended up buying those cars for about $20,000 off, since there were other incentives—like , “damn, we need to get rid of this turd, which is really a great car, but nobody seems willing to pay $55,000 for it.”

the only rebates bmw is allowed to even advertise are those for the bmw club members who buy new or cpo cars and those are advertised as a club benefit, not truly advertised in any other media. 

a few years back, porsche na started a similar rebate program with the porsche club, and, damn, did the suits in germany get freaked out about that. they would never be caught pitching a rebate, no matter which car (boxster) and which person (a person belong to a club for your very consumerist product) it was for. so, that ended rather quickly.

i’ve told this story before, but i’ll retell it here because it’s appropriate. years ago, i was in an art class which had loads and loads of old magazines to use as “art fodder”. after a while, i discovered that among those old magazines were old issues of national geographic. like, really old. i wondered if they might contain car ads, so i started flipping through, and to my delight, they did! knowing these magazines were going to inevitably be hacked up by other students, i asked if i could spend any free time in class removing the old car ads so i could take them home, and the teacher said yes. by the time i was no longer in that class, i had collected over 180 vintage car ads ranging from 1946 to 1964, most in near-mint condition. i’ve never photographed my collection, but i found a few images of ones that i have:

early last year, my wife really wanted a 2018 rogue (fine, whatever) and i noticed a new, 2017 model murano advertised for virtually the same price on a local dealer’s website. we went to the dealer to check out the murano and after driving it, we were told that the price was correct, but that we had to qualify for tons of special promotions to get it. of course, they were things like student discount, military discount, etc. all told, the price of the car was several thousand more than advertised. i personally believe that the murano was a bait car the website used to get people in the door in order to sell their customers on a lesser, more popular vehicle that would actually go for the advertised price. it worked for us, because my poor wife fell in love with a blue rogue on the lot and we bought it—what she wanted all along—but i’ll be damned if i ever fall for that shit again.

call me stupid, but i feel that this problem (and the over-all copy-rights take-down issue that youtube is getting raked over the coals with by creators and viewers alike) is a much simpler solve to do but harder for certain parties to accept. that is, no automated take-downs of alleged copy right infringement. it must be a) manually reported by a person via a message to a youtube claims address, b) the claim be reviewed by a person to see if it is valid, c) the video in question remains up and accessible until it is manually determined that it is in violation, d) only during the review process would ad revenues be suspended, but not outright cancelled,

a little education here:  f1m may not be the party to blame here.  youtube has a program in place where a content owner can upload a copy of their video (original or a “fingerprint”), and youtube’s algorithms will cross-analyze content uploaded by other users against it.  if it determines a certain level of confidence of a match, it’ll automatically take it down and file a claim on behalf of the content owner (or, in some cases, they can actually claim ownership and keep the video up, but they receive all viewership ad revenue).  unfortunately, it’s a cat and mouse game.  piracy is still a problem, and pirates are getting more and more creative about how they pirate content.  in many cases, its video effect filters, translations, inversions, etc.  if the youtube algos get too liberal, they can intersect on genuine content like this.

interest rates were historically low from 2008 to 2015, because of the recession, when the fed kept the rate at 0%. then in 2015 they finally started raising the interest rate, and if you look at this chart, the fed raised rates three times in 2017, and four times in 2018! and they have stated that they’re going to keep raising them. the days of 1.9% interest rates on a 6 year old car, like i got a few years ago when i bought my last car and financed through my credit union, are gone. these days, my credit union prime rates are at 3.6% to 4% on a used car. usaa, a pretty impressively low rate lender, advertises 3.09% on a new car, or 3.74% on a used car. so 3% is about the absolute best that you’re going to get. you can find lower, like penfed credit union advertises 2.5% on new and 3.5% on used, but as you see, these are significantly higher than the 1.4% or whatever they were on used cars in 2014-2015.

in nebraska, i cannot advertise any rebates that have quealifiers as part of a price. i have to have a separate line with a disclaimer clearly stating the conditions. if you choose to ignore that disclaimer, that’s not my fault. i will clearly spell it out in e-mail and phone as well what the requirements are.

not entirely true. in fact, most national lease deals are advertised at invoice or near invoice at the lowest possible money factor and acquisition fee, much to the chagrin of dealerships. the only caveat is that you need to be alright with the advertised trim, which typically includes base models and 2wd suv’s. still, they are actually good deals.

i can only speak for what i do, but the cash back deals are available to anyone and we are not allowed to advertise stacking stuff that you need to qualify for, ie. college grad, military and friends and family all in one cash back offer. the only caveat that i can think of is apr, which you have to qualify via credit score. other than that our ads would say, $x cash back on a my ‘xx. i know their is shady shit out there, but just because some things are does not mean they all are.
yea, of course, all our ads have disclaimers, but as you well know people don’t read those most of the time.

drivetrain/fuel system: - currently has 74k on it; m46 has about 4k; 18t has 38k (as of 192000)



*completely rebuilt motor and transmission - a 1993 squirter b230et 
(using euro et tight squish pistons). about 220hp and runs flawlessly on
 87 octane.

*new 18t mitsubishi turbo with a ported and flowed manifold

*hallman adjustable mbc (master boost controller) set to 13lbs of boost.

*recent 1991 m46 with new clutch, pressure plate, flywheel, throw-out bearing, new slave and master cylinders, etc.

*v-cam with adjustable timing gear as well.

*stock lh2.4 engine management, but a lh2.2 throttle-body to allow for adjustments if needed



the engine was built by “stealthfti” who also installed the m46 manual transmission. it is “project 15a” in his pbase gallery. 

the engine has lived on mobil-1 synthetic since birth, with a brief period of amsoil 20w50 racing oil. 



more engine particulars are detailed at the bottom.



*new 3-core hd radiator 

*new 100a alternator 

*new power steering pump/rack/hoses

*replaced/rebuilt the entire ac system, ice cold (r134a), and yes, the automatic climate control works with no leaky bellows!



*new fuel pumps

*balanced/blueprinted injectors (rc engineering), and in-tank sending unit.

*upgraded the fuel tank from a 60l to a 75l from a later 960 wagon

 -the sender doesn’t ‘see’ the extra volume, so you have a very large 
reserve when the needle is on ‘empty’. this has to do with the sender 
matching the gauge and not the larger tank.



*mandrel bent free flow 3" exhaust from downpipe to tailpipe.





wheels, tires & suspension: currently has about 22k on it (as of 192000)



*cross drilled rotors front & back

*updated front “jumbo” brakes from a 94 940 (larger than the ‘regular’ ones on the 760)

*new calipers

*new brake lines

*new brake booster

*new master cylinder

*all new parking brake cables.

*new wheel bearings

*new u-joints

*ipd upper and lower support braces

*ipd swaybars

*all new poly bushings

*new ball joints

*new tie rod ends

*new upper strut mounts

*new overload coil springs in the rear.



the car has a very nice set volvo’s “nova” rims (for the early volvo 960) with 5k mile kumho tires. 



interior: 



*seats, steering wheel, sun visors (with lighted mirrors), center 
armrest, carpeted mats and lighted window switches (in the rear too) are
 from 1997 volvo 960 (more plush, nicer looking and  comfortable).

*stripped, power washed and re-dyed the carpets. brand-new headliner (for a 1997 volvo 960).

*300 sq ft of sound deadening material covering every surface (including roof).

*no cracks in the dash, nor any splits in the upholstery.



the sound system will blow you out of the car;

*brand new cd head unit w/ipod controls (via usb front input, which accepts a thumb drive too)

*boston acoustic speakers all around

*subwoofer in custom enclosure to fit inside the spare wheel

*10 disc mp3 changer

*wired for satellite radio - antenna pulled above the headliner

*viper keyless entry (alarm not enabled, only locking doors/tailgate and flashing led in the dash)



*custom gauge cluster in the center, the climate controls moved to the lower radio position. 



*floor mats, and a cut-to-size cargo mat in the back to protect the carpet from tears and dirt. 

 



body:



*new 960 glass moonroof (the original 760 is a solid metal sunroof)

*euro roof rails from later 960, dealership installed - the cross bars

*european turn-signals (clear, dual-bulb setup, see below for details)

*turbo “eggcrate” grill

*windshield and rear hatch trims swapped for black trim

you’re typically paying for it one way or the other, is the thing. we might in some situations “show” $10k for your trade, but in all reality it’s acv’d, or actual cash valued for $8k. that $2k is, theoretically, buried in what you pay for the car.
 
pro-tip: i work for a highline european dealer in the midwest and my favorites to sell are certified loaner cars. management is far more desperate to get rid of them due to pressure from the brand, and typically as the salesperson you’ve got more of a leash to close a deal, whether it be negotiating on the trade or the sale price.

ultimately the sales person not caring about how much they fork over for your trade would be a losing strategy, because there’s a pretty good chance that you’re the sales guy that would have to turn around and sell that car...very least, sell it for close to asking and make next to nothing for your time, or spend forever negotiating with someone, again, making next to nothing for the time you’ve invested, or, it sits on the lot forever because of the above and eventually sells for a sometimes not insignificant loss.

expecting to go into a dealership on a used or cpo car and expecting thousands off asking price will get you nowhere except being “that guy” that the sales staff knows will be a time-suck from experience.  the internet has made purchasing from auction difficult, and impossible for a dealer to move units that are advertised well above market value.  only way to be successful is to shoot straight.  /fin

georgia caved to the car dealership lobby a few years back. you pay the tax all up front when you first tag a vehicle, new or used - private sale or dealer. if you’re a jalop and you keep swapping out your car every year or two you get absolutely hammered on tax. used to you’d pay sales tax from a dealer (overall value could be offset by that of your trade in) but not a private party sale. you’d just pay the small yearly ad valorem tax based on the then-current value....if you swapped the car a year later you were just out the $200 or whatever for the year, not thousands as it currently stands. i know of a few people who register in montana and every single one of them started doing this after the law changed.  also, when my wife totaled her car 15 months after we bought it we lit that $3800 in up-front tax on fire and got to spend it again when we replaced the car.
it’s not a sales tax. i think there would be less dodging if it was, since it could be itemized on your income taxes. as it is, it’s a ad valorem tax, which is not deductible.

calm down. your information is outdated, georgia stopped the annual ad valorem tax a couple of years ago. you now pay a one-time upfront tavt (title ad valorem tax) when purchasing/registering your vehicle.

year was 1983 my parents had 3 kids 9, 8, and 6. being young parents they finally had some money to buy a new car compared to used  junkers they had been driving for the past 10 years or so. you’d think they’d get a wagon, one of those new mini vans that just came out, sedan, or at least something that sat 5 people but this was a time before anybody cared about car seats or seatbelts. the first car my mom looked at was a new firebird with those cool pop up headlights but she didn’t like how you could see everything in the hatch area. then they were about to buy a used 78 jaguar xjs but the dealership wouldn’t put the car on the lift so my dad could see where the oil leak was coming from. so while the 5 of us were driving back from the ground round in a 78 single cab f100 we stopped at a ford lincoln mercury dealership. where my sisters and i spent 3+ hours sitting in the truck while my parents bought an 83 mercury cougar. if you are not familar with what that is, it’s basiclly a fox body mustang with a little more rear over hang that provided a bigger trunk. it only sat 4 people which means anytime the 5 of us went some place someone got stuck riding on the “hump” in the back seat. it wasn’t bad at first but kids don’t stay the same size and getting crammed in the back seat got old after a year or 2. my mom still won’t admit it was a bad idea, her excuse is she was 29 and no way was she going to be seen in a 4 door car.

i don’t know how it is overseas but we have a thing calls a priority market area, which is the area your customers should come from. a good trick is to get a quote from a dealer of the same brand that isn’t your closest dealer. take that quote back to your closest dealer and there is a very good chance they’ll sit up and beg as it is very bad news not to sell to your pma. 
major metro dealers are usually your best shot for deals in australia, they tend to only want major volume as they have enormous targets to achieve and get the biggest rewards for exceeding them and every unit over counts. 
finance will get you a deal over cash as cash just gets them a number finance gets them profits. most brand new cars and even used cars have next to zero margin in them. they’re usually sold on “load” which is the calculated cost of selling the car e.g advertising, fuel, detailing, insurance etc. 
after sales surveys, modern new car dealerships live and die by these surveys. if you are unhappy and they’re not coming to the party you can hold them to ransom with these as it is worth major dollars to them to get 100% score on every survey.

i used to sell advertising to car dealers. you can spot the ones trying to make month-end quotas because they’ll run super-aggressive print or radio ads during the last few days of the month. keep in mind too that not all months close on the 31st, especially if near a holiday. the one you want is the one that is just a couple of cars short of hitting a performance tier - losing a couple grand on a car doesn’t matter to them if it gets them an extra $500 profit on all the other cars they sold that month.  the sales manager has already done that math.  if they’re well short of the goal towards the end of the month

i’m not a huge mustang guy either, but i was basically forced to borrow a mustang gt the other day, and comrade, let me tell you: i am a believer now. as has been said in these comments ad infinitum, 480 hp for ~50k is unreal. yet, to me, equally important was that it never felt unhinged like so many other high-horses cars i’ve driven. as much as i usually decry the bigger-is-better mindset, i think the size is necessary here. power was there in spades when you wanted it, but you never felt like the car was about to lurch you off a bridge if you blinked while on the throttle, i believe due in no small part to the physical size of the car. i’m not a deep pedigree driver by any means, but i was gob-smacked by how impressive the gt was, and what a completely different car the package made it. if you put a gun to my head and made me buy a new car today, i have to admit i would urinate on the grave of my “found on road dead” ancestry and buy a gt, no question.

some folks (like me) prefer the sc model (‘78-’83), others the later 80s carrera (‘84-’89). they’re pretty similar on the surface, but the sc has the 3.0 liter with cis injection, and the more mechanical-feeling 915 gearbox, and the carrera has an updated 3.2 l engine, with dme engine management (controls both injection and timing; i understand some guys carry a spare dme module in case of failure) and the later carreras have the g50 transmission, which is supposed to be more rugged (it’s throw is shorter, and it feels more stout. i prefer the earlier 915 , with the slower, long and more mechanically involved shifting!). these cars can still be found in the price range you’re talking about, with lots of miles or not a lot (i found my car, 49,000 miles, with a rebuilt engine, trans, cis , new clutch ). i found mine on cargurus, but i also looked at the classified ads in panorama. search the craigslist ads, i’ve seen ads from reputable sellers there too.

since you asked...fixed headlamp glass with such a rake greatly reduces the light output.  combined with the small real estate under the fixed lamps means there isn’t much light output to start with because the lamp reflectors are small.  pop ups also raise the headlamp mounting height, increasing driver vision down-road.  the car is lowered, so it’s a double reduction in height and probably not street legal.  aftermarket headlamps are also typically short lived as they don’t have the r&d of a major lighting manufacturer.  using the oem porsche lamps fixes all of these, even if it looks weird.

the 100d is advertised as having 335 miles of range. this truck will presumably have worse aerodynamics, even if they make it all swoopy and fancy like in the picture, and i would imagine be heavier. even if not, i assume battery capacity to range is pretty linear.

500 miles of range would thus require more like a 150kwh battery, and if efficiency goes down due to weight/shape of the truck, maybe more like 175. 

in any case, even *if* they get the cost down to $100 per kwh, which i’ll believe when i see (remember, the model x was supposed to cost $45k when it was announced...) that’s still a $10,000 battery minimum, but likely more like $15k or $17.5k. and that’s *just* the cost of the battery, not the whole truck.

i see the chances of this costing less than 50k to be extremely unlikely, and i bet they’re going to aim higher and try to fit this out as a $90,000+ truck alongside the model s and x.

that does suck. the proprietary cms i’m developing will handle that. if you change the url for typo reasons, it will keep the old one in the database, but issue an seo-safe 301 redirect to the new url. that way, you’re not tethered to the original url, but don’t lose your backlinks over changing it, either.

that said, your seo score does go down by 10-15% with a 301 redirect, which isn’t a big deal for a small website, but is a significant amount in raw numbers and lost advertising for a giant news aggregator like jalopnik. i suspect that’s why jalopnik probably doesn’t encourage changing urls after articles have been published, even if kinja has a similar function.

those technical words are typically just conjugations of multiple words. for instance, porsche’s pdk transmission - porsche doppelkupplung. doppelkupplung translates to two words in english; double coupling, which we would call a dual clutch. it makes sense when its broken down, its just similar but slightly different words that english speakers would use.

it’s really nothing like that at all. reporting “a car using ‘autopilot’ crashed” is factual news reporting. analyzing how exactly that car crashed is extremely important for improving said “autopilot” system so maybe next time it doesn’t run into the back of a fire truck. do they get more coverage than regular car crashes? of course they do, just like how the moon landings got more coverage than the last gps satellite launch. it’s new technology with a controversial application method, and most importantly people are interested in it which means the articles will attract attention (and ad money).

i would think we could start with being a bit more responsible with our headlines. as you said, it’s all about attention and ad money, so the headlines are written in the most sensationalist way possible. most of the time they are written so as to make it sound as though autopilot was the main issue. for example, instead of “driver admits not paying attention when tesla rear-ended fire truck”, we tend to get things like, “driver states autopilot was on when tesla rear-ended fire truck.”

not only does this sound like it’s mainly an autopilot issue, it also draws attention away from the fact that driver inattentiveness is also a problem which needs to be sorted out.

it doesn’t take a genius to figure out that most people will always take the easiest path when doing a chore as they’d rather be doing something else.  driving is no different.  people would rather be entertained than having to drive.  no doubt elon musk knows this.  and yet he’s allowed one of the single most dangerous systems to be placed in his car’s and be activated even though he claims that its still in beta testing.  so if it’s still being tested, why are these tesla owners being charged $5,000 to use a system that’s still under test and evaluation?  elon must know that anyone willing to pay that much is going to use the system, and they’re going to use the system so they can do other things...like read, sleep, or otherwise entertain themselves.  but they’re not just endangering themselves, they’re endangering us as well.  and to be frank, elon musk has no right to put my life in danger over his highly flawed self driving feature.  elon also knows that most people won’t ever even bother reading the owner’s manual so all his warnings, etc... that he’s put in there are completely useless.  and totally unrealistic.  we can’t even get people to stop using their cellphones while driving, so why would elon think for even a second that people using his self driving system are actually going to pay attention to the car’s driving?  first off, anything that’s still in beta testing has no business being released to the general public.  and not just released, but to charge customers for the option as though it was a finished product.  and just how long will tesla claim that the system is still in beta testing anyhow?  it seems that tesla’s using that as a scapegoat so they can duck responsibility.  the truth is, tesla’s system is far inferior to the “supercruise” that gm offers in the cadillac ct6.  gm’s system ensures that the driver is actually paying attention.  tesla’s doesn’t.  i see these accidents as being both the driver’s and tesla’s fault.  tesla’s for putting a system in a car that can be easily misunderstood/misused by a driver that didn’t bother to read the fine print and the driver’s for just being too stupid to realize that tesla didn’t create an imaginary driver that can take over driving responsibilities at the pull of a lever (x2).  tesla needs to stop hiding behind fine print and take responsibility for their actions.  their bold print in their advertising clearly claims that they’ve got “self driving” capabilities.

automotive engineers and the detroit car company executives generally hate the whole idea of electric cars. they all got into the business because they love internal combustion engines, and the disdain they have for electric is barely disguised in the way they talk about the alternatives. the underfunded ad campaign for the chevy volt is nothing but a subtle insult. “electric when you want it, gas when you need it.” why not just say, “electric when you’re a little crybaby and gas for when you grow a pair and realize that real red-blooded men don’t drive around in battery powered toys!” i have spoken personally to gm engineers, both in the traditional and electric side of the business and they openly acknowledge that the company is loaded with people who absolutely despise the idea of replacing their lineup with electric vehicles. it has nothing to do with profits or a big oil conspiracy. it boils down to personal prejudices that compete against actual wise business decisions. for what it’s worth, i’m told by these same execs that it’s really not much different in europe or japan where the entrenched industry people just eat breath and sleep petroleum. i guess it would be like telling the top brass at mcdonald’s that they’re going to stop selling hamburgers made out of beef. no matter what you tell them they aren’t going to get on board.

you have no idea what you are talking about. while the most common type of vehicle detectors technically operate based on electromagnetic principles, they are not magnetic sensors. what you are referring to, but clearly do not actually understand, are inductive loops. an electric current is run through wire loops embedded in the pavement, and when a large metal object moves over the loops, the inductance of the circuit changes, which is how the signal controller is alerted to the presence of a vehicle. the other technologies that you reference are never used for vehicle detection. light beam interrupters are only ever used in overheight vehicle warning systems, and pressure sensors are not used in any way. the other common types of vehicle detection used at signalized intersections are microwave, video, and ir video. also, the type of detection used at an intersection is never changed based on time of day. usually only one type of detection is installed at an intersection, and if there are multiple types, they are used for redundancy, not switched on ad off at different times of the day. again, i believe what you were trying to refer to, but clearly do not fully understand, was the difference between tod timing plans and fully actuated operation. it is true that most signals operate a different timing plan during peak periods, but that doesn’t mean the vehicle detection is turned off, it just means that there are longer min green times for the major movements and the controller will not be as responsive to a call placed from a side street.

engineers use these numbers to build routes to decrease traffic jams. it helps to determine which materials to use on the road. heavier traffic needs tougher materials which are more expensive. it also helps outdoor advertising companies to measure the audience that pass by their billboards. whether or not they look at the billboards is another question. i never thought twice about why those tubes were being used.

from 1972 to 1986, my mother drove a datsun 610 wagon with a manual transmission. it was purple with a white vinyl interior. she only stopped driving it because it didn’t have air conditioning, and because my parents bought a 1985 ram charger so we could tow a little pop-up camper around on vacations. that glorious wagon sat in our driveway for a couple of years, just waiting for me to get my driver’s license. i didn’t ask, i just assumed that it would become mine. 4 months before my 16th birthday, my father let someone have it for free just to get it out of our driveway. i walked home from school one fall afternoon in ‘88 and it was just gone. i’ve never seen another 610 wagon in real life, and i haven’t even been able to find a photo of a factory purple one or one with a white interior on the internet. if my father was resurrected, i’m not sure which i’d do first, hug him or call him a fucking dickhead. but it’s my fault. i never asked for the car. it was a lot like the ‘74 wagon in the background of this ad, but the color of the sedan in the foreground:

skyf1 is by far the best f1 coverage an f1 fan could ask for. when i watched their stream, they played the commercials before and after the race...never during the race when things tend to happen in a split second. i hated nbc’s coverage because of that. at times they showed a small banner with the ads...i didnt like it but it was ok because at least you could still see wwhat was going on. other times they cut the race in key moments for the ads just like espn did on that feed and that’s unacceptable. f1 is not nba or nfl unless there’s is a safety car out on track, there’s no pause, no time outs for bs ads.

i’m just glad i wasn’t the only one that disliked espn’s take on f1 broadcasting. it seems like no one a espn understands that f1 is not nascar. it isn’t a 5 hour race that needs constant ads to keep the fans interested. and it also seems they think that team radio is a  good time to mute the race and show some more ads. the race comes back on after a few minutes, the announcers have no idea that we missed all of that and no one explains what happened or what they were talking about.

so espn apologizes for technical issues. that really wasn’t the problem. stuff happens. and, to my eyes, the coverage was good. i just have to get used to the new broadcasters, sort of like breaking in a new pair of shoes. the real problem is how to fit commercials when using somebody elses feed. we miss out on the coverage during the breaks, and there is no mechanism to review what we missed. i find that disrespectful to the fans, to formula 1 and to the advertisers.

as an entrepreneur, consultant to large companies, gearhead/fan and active youtube publisher, i get it. if it were just frieberger and finnegan, i would support the move, but this is discovery communications (old school media co) not wanting to share margin with youtube (silicon valley media co). while their policies are getting worse and worse, and the ads are annoying, youtube is still pretty damn far away from from the sheer agony that is network/cable tv.

on the even larger scale — youtube hasn’t been all that well off in the past either. all of the tight ad cuts came from new leadership put in place by google. youtube never turned a profit until a year or two ago and they’re still not doing

it sounds like you don’t know all the money that goes into reconditioning a car for retail sale. many people would not buy their car again in the condition they trade it in, even though when they’re trading it in they’ll fight tooth and nail to tell you that it’s flawless. the truth is that the average shop bill on a car that gets retailed is just under 1000 dollars. and then when you break down an advertising budget, each car takes up another couple hundred dollars. and on top of that the dealer has to detail the car twice (once to go on the lot, again after the sale). and then has to pay their people out of the profit. all in all, offering a $500 concession to a customer can usually eat up 25-30% of your profit margin. but please, tell me again how you were “ripped off”. 🙄

if you notice in some of the commercials, the honda prelude in particular, you see “verno” advertised at the end of it. they were specialized dealerships in japan that honda created to make them distinct from other products they sell (ie: motorcycles, lawnmowers, etc.). the prelude was the first car to be featured in this dealership configuration. they later made honda clio (for luxury cars), and honda primo (for family cars). by the mid 2000's, they ended up doing away with all these and made standard dealerships. here’s a good writeup about them:

i’m in mexico, so craiglist is barely used here. we have a lot of similar platforms and while i use most of them, when it comes to selling cars, the newspaper with more circulation in the city is always the best bet, if you buy an ad for 3 days it will also grant you a space on their web/app catalog for an extra 12 days which is a nice bonus.

there’s a formula here: 
you send the ad on thursday, so it comes on the printed newspaper friday, saturday and sunday (sometimes they give you monday for free) because life is so damn busy here that you will likely only have time to show the car or search for one on the weekend, also it’s more likely that the ad you see only on the weekend is from a particular with an urgency to sell (because you have to pay for the ad), hence most people think “the price will be at it’s lowest and there will even be some room to haggle”. only people who owns car lots buy the full week since they buy at volume, and you pretty much steer away from those unless you don’t give a crap or don’t know better.

they don’t have to guarantee a specific number. when you advertise that a product can accomplish something, the implication, both informally and legally, is that it should be able to accomplish a reasonable person’s interpretation of that claim. it doesn’t have to survive a day at the nordschleife under race conditions but a reasonable interpretation of that would be that it sure as hell should make it more than half a dozen reasonably aggressive laps before going belly up. 

contrary to popular belief and “buyer beware” sentiment, making your claims excessively vague and then using that ambiguity to jump through loopholes when you can’t live up to the spirit of those claims isn’t legally viable. at the end of the day the advertised features of a product are part of the contractual obligations of the purchase and the associated warranty unless they go out of their way to exclude them specifically, and for this specific reason, ambiguity or lack of clarity in a contract pretty much always comes down in favor of the party who did not write it. if gm advertised a track-ready car and it can’t do a reasonable number of laps, it isn’t track-ready, full stop. all the puffery about “structures and technologies” is irrelevant.

that’s kinda my point though, i don’t remember any specific claims about track ready in advertising done by gm. if the advertisement said anything about being track ready, then yeah. but those words never came from gm, just all the media outlets covering it.
i don’t practice in this area, but from what i recall, i believe most states will not go to great lengths to hold nonspecific advertising claims against a manufacturer.

that’s the thing. gm doesn’t have to have made specific literal claims about performance or trackability (probably a made up word but i like it). the lawsuit appears to be arguing that it’s the message they deliberately embedded into their advertising. whether it was explicitly stated or by implication matters less than whether or not a court will say a reasonable person would walk away from that advertising interpreting it to mean such a thing.

i think you’re right but generally the issues at hand are a lot more subjective (i.e. it usually has to do with what someone defines good/great to be or something equally nebulous). this is systemic to a specific problem. it looks to me like the lawsuit is suggesting that even if the specific literal statements were vague that the collective claim they implied was far more direct. i think they filed in federal court (which i guess makes sense considering that the nationwide status of the class and the advertising regulations involved) which i suspect will be a little less sympathetic to word games.

this is nothing new, car dealers have been doing this for a very long time.  in 92 i sold cars for 6 months and that was the normal practice, advertised price of everything did not include, freight, taxes, fees, etc...and included any rebates.  everything was fully disclosed in very small print in the ads and fully disclosed when they were in the box (finance), totally legal and all dealers seems to do it too but it is not very ethical.

i would posit that the question to ask is, “what is the dollar amount of the check i am going to have to write you today to purchase this car including all fees and taxes.”  as long as cars under consideration are equally optioned, there isn’t any way to hide; the price is the price.  a dealer that adds on fake charges, cooperative advertising group surcharge, etc. is going to come out costing more.

i don’t think the guy at trout unlimited is worried about serious off-roaders, so you’re in the clear. the problem is all of the idiots who vacation in with their jeep from somewhere without public land and try off-roading on public land like they see in the advertisements, because they don’t know better and think disclaimers like the one in the ad don’t apply to them. good behavior in the back country isn’t as intuitive for a lot of people as many other examples set in advertising are. if you need proof that people like that exist, just look for trash at unmaintained campsites.

i 100% agree that there is a problem, i am very aware that the closer i camp to a road the crapier the campsites always are. the last place i camped near the road i had to clean up a freaking box spring! that being said, i don’t buy the argument that this ad encourages reckless behaviour anymore than does living and breathing does for people who are prone to damaging habits. they know they are being stupid and reckless and they don’t care, in fact...that’s part of the fun! “tear’n it up!”. i think the only way to combat this type of bad behaviour is to get people excited about nature so they will understand that their choices have consequences that matter to them. its to move away from a “muddin it” attitude to a “hey, i like this place...don’t wreck it for me alright?” attitude.

we’re on the same side, so i’m not very concerned about our differences in opinion. the first type of person i think of though related to all of this are people who go to ouray and rent a jeep. they’re not interested enough in off roading to have ever looked anything up about it, they just assume that they can do like they see in the ads because they’ve seen no better example to follow. so they rent a jeep, make a mess of something, and have no idea they did anything wrong, and aren’t invested enough to actually learn. the same thing applies to a person who drives in from somewhere without public land and decides to try off-roading for the first time ever. their only examples of off roading may be from questionable sources, so it would be nice if jeep took a responsible stance in their advertising like you said.

i never commit ever. but this one hits close to home. 1990 454ss was my first truck i had it from 95 to 01. 7.4 throttle body 400 turbo they had the red interior with buckets and factory center console which was unheard of unless you had a bronco suburban are k5 at the time. if it was friday night i was at praire hill drag strip. anyone who knows chevy you always get more than what’s advertised. never ever put it on the dyno. we didn’t even really know what one was back then and no one had them around central texas. maybe in dallas. but here are the facts. the truck would run. every time slip i ever ran was in the high 13s. except for once i ran a 15 because the tbi had to be cleaned and was popping and cutting out. zero to 60 was insane. from a dead stop it would throw your head back in first second and third. tires factory were 275 60 r15. big for the time but the toqure was crazy. couldn’t and wouldn’t drive it if it rained you would just sit still spinning. you would never catch traction are you would go sideways. fact never got out ran by a mustang are camaro svt or z28 until the 97 z28 came. i never won against a c5 or newer vette. so my buddies no matter what they had new ford are ram 318 340 even had a buddy with a 440 he put in a old step side ram and also ate plenty 351 and 302 ford’s. bad thing about the truck true never got better or worse than 10 mpg. old men would always tell me would pass anything but a gas station. pretty much true. ran like shit on unlead had to buy the good stuff. also fact not the same 7.4 in burbs and duallys way hotter motor but with the same tq. the truck would handle when dry very well. bad thing but prob good for me it didn’t waste no time from 0 -115 mph. for some reason never could get it over that like it needed a another gear are two. everyone looked at truck. everyone wanted that truck. but there were faster cheyennes with 350s and 5 speed man that were faster some dirt track boys would modify and whoop everything. the truck became obsolete the day chevy cane out with the 5.3 vortec. way to many cheap mods to get it pushing 500 hp and 500 lbs and could get it in a superlite fiberglass step side reg cab. i do wish i still had the monster. was my first love. even though gas is no longer .69 a gallon. and for you ford boys. raced several new lightings too after they came out. came close a few times with the superchargers but one never got that old 1990 454ss. and it was all factory. the old gas days are over of the small and big blocks. well be racing electric trucks soon. and nothing gas will touch them.

great post, but to be serious about your point: i’m confident that it’s legit. first thing i do when i suspect a scam ad is reverse image search the lead photo to see if they stole it from wikipedia or something. in this case there were no results, so the photos are original (and google’s best guess is that it’s a mazda, lol). also, there are actual telephone numbers, which usually isn’t the case with scammers. plus this is not a desirable car, it has a niche market at best, and the price is reasonable but not into insane steal category, which is what most scammers do to optimize the number of people that will reply. i think this is just a case of someone that did a photoshoot of their car in the summer and used those pictures because they look great.

it may not have been a “could they see it” problem so much as an “it couldn’t react” problem. adaptive cruise control is intended to be used when the vehicles are traveling somewhere close to the same speed. in this case, the car had to see the firetruck, see that it was stationary, and then stop the car from what the firemen say was 65 mph. if the speed limit is 65, the smart money is betting the car was doing more than that. remember, this emergency stop stuff in the commercials is often advertised in parking lots or city streets, where the car (1) has more time to realize what’s going on and (2) has a much shorter stopping distance.

iihs is what all the oems want to advertise now, since it’s generally accepted those tests are more strict than us gov, so iihs is becoming our standard. iihs sets tolerances for cabin intrusion and greenhouse deformation that at or above what he government thinks a vehicle should be. if you design a car to pass the test, it’s easy to be top of the class. redesigning an apron and a pillar over a few years is difficult, but not impossible. honda did it between the 2012 and 2013 civic by changing the front bumper reinforcement geometry. i look at wrecked cars all day, i’ve yet to see an alfa, but i’d be very curious to see one with the front end apart and compare that to mercedes architecture that was in development around the same time.

i feel like i’ve gotten pretty lucky with the cars i’ve purchased over the years. but i’ve heard of, and witnessed, a lot of insanely sketchy deals go down. the one that instantly came to mind was another chapter in my saga of searching for a volvo 242/245 turbo in the late ‘90s. very rarely, one would pop up at an area dealership, and basically 100% of the time, they were hot garbage. there was that phantom demand for them, though, and the dealers seemed to know it.

my dad was shopping for his “old man convertible” and found a 1996 bmw z3 that had been converted to an m roadster (s52 swap and a bunch of other upgrades)in about 2009. it was about $7500. i showed the ad to my wife, she said “let’s get it!” who am i to argue. subday night we went to look at it, looked nice, drove great, agreed to pay the seller’s price, wrote out a bill of sale, left a deposit and agreed to come back in a day or two with the balance and pick up the car. the price was really a stretch for my budget. it took two days to get the funds together. monday night i call the seller and he tells me he sold the car to someone else willing to pay more. several heated phone calls and threats of lawsuits later, we agree that i will pick up the car on tuesday. i get the car from the most unhappy seller. it is great, fast and quick. about a week and less than 500 miles later something is wrong. a trip to the shop reveals that something “catastrophic” happened to one of the cylinders and it need a new engine. i stretch my credit cards another $4.5k for a junkyard engine and a shadetree mechanic to install it. everything is ok for about 10 months, except that i have to register the car at my parents house because it won’t pass emissions due to electrical fiddling with the engine swap. then it starts running really rough again. i replace coil packs and try to fix it myself with no luck. a trip to the shop reveals a warpped head! after about 3 months in the shop and another $4k or so on my already strained credit cards i get a running car back. by this point baby is on the way and a 2 seat sports car is not an acceptable dad vehicle. by this point i’m terrified of every squeak and rattle in the car. i end up buying a new silverado extended cab 6 cylinder automatic work truck as my dad vehicle (5 year 100k powertrain warranty is very comforting). the bmw goes up for sale. after many months i finally sell it for about $6k, the not passing emissions thing was a bigger problem than anticipated. so for only about $10k, i got the privilege of driving a fast, but temperamental, 15 year old bmw for a total of about 10 months.
